title: @Meddler : intent with the new Warlord Bloodlust on PBE
body:
Hi,

There is currently a version of Warlord Bloodlust on the PBE that gives only Lifesteal. No more AS, no more Crit synergy. So what are the goal of this change?

More specific points:

* Who are the intended users? Does removing Crit synergy mean that non-ADC are now supposed to go for this keystone?
* What is the differentiation point between Fervor of Battle and Warlord? Both look good for extended fights, which fits well with the Red tree being the tree for DPS (vs the Purple tree for Burst) and they both apply to basic attack only. But why take one over the other, except just mathematically one is better than the other?

Side question: I always felt that one of the many reasons Thunderlord was crowding other options was because it was MUCH better in early game, even if it fell off in later stages of the game. So are Keystone intended to have "powerspike", so to speak? I'm not sure it's a good idea, because it restricts probably too much who can use what keystone.
My guess is that no, they are not intended to have powerspike, hence the removal of the Crit synergy, that is not good in early game (before building Crit). Also, most other keystones scale with levels or are % amplifications, in order to stay relatively steady in power provided throughout the game.

replies.body:
The revised Warlord's is intended to be attractive to champions that repeatedly auto attack who are seeking sustain rather than damage (contrast with Fervor) and in a way that scales with offensive stats like crit, AS and Armor Pen, rather than defense (contrast with Grasp). We expect marksmen to be one of the primary groups Warlord's appeals to as a result, though probably not the only ones. Fervor should be particularly appealing if you've got a team offering a lot of peel or are intending to grab lifesteal elsewhere, Warlord's if you want some build path flexibility and have other strong damage sources on your team.

The strong crit synergy unfortunately felt like it restricted our ability to balance Warlord's for a range of champions more than it allowed cool interactions with specific kits. 

We also feel that masteries can't be too spikey in terms of early versus late game performance. Some masteries slanting towards strength in particular parts of the game is fine. Masteries that just don't contribute anything early game by contrast would need to be ridiculously powerful late game, given how the early game feeds into mid/late game.

What do you think the chances are of this item leading certain marksmen to opt for more raw damage (Infinity Edge, Armor Penetration) and forgo lifesteal items (BoRK, Bloodthirster) entirely?  

Lifesteal Quints and Vampirism combined with the new Warlord's Bloodlust could easily be enough to replace a dedicated lifesteal item on most marksmen at the cost of 15% attack speed early-game.

Many marksmen could benefit from having space to purchase a full defensive item without having to sacrifice critical strike chance, attack speed, or armor penetration items.
--------------------
Also, is it safe to assume that Warlord's Bloodlust will only heal you for damage dealt to enemy champions and minions?  That is, it won't heal you based on damage dealt to wards, jungle monsters and/or champion pets.

I think it's reasonable to believe that some marksmen might forgo a lifesteal item and take Warlord's instead, though we might not see that initially (or might see it too often if the launch balance is overtuned). 

The healing from Warlord's is going to be regular lifesteal but only against champions and minions. That will function against player summoned minions, but won't do anything against wards or jungle monsters.

Are there any plans to make changes to other keystones to be more relevant to junglers while they're actually in the jungle? Right now the only ones they directly benefit from through the whole game are in Resolve (Bond of Stone and Strength of Ages).
Preventing Warlord's from working on jungle monsters just out of fear of it becoming the dominant jungle keystone really seems like a cop out.
Shouldn't every tree have something relevant for junglers? 

(Some quick ideas that come to mind would be allowing Fervor and/or Deathfire to work on monsters (maybe have Fervor stack separately from the champion stacks or reduce Deathfire's damage when used on monsters to prevent potential abuse?) and adding "or killing a jungle monster" to Stormraider's.)
I support this.

I have one issue with this. If this is supposed to promote build flexibility, where are the options for other classes? Mages can't opt out of mana/CDR or self-peel (their only defensive tool) and instead have to rely on items (2 for CDR, one or more for mana, though its sometimes included via regen, which is offered), and non-tank supports can't really take anything except windspeaker or thunderlord's, mostly because if you aren't a healer or a tank, there's no option other than thunderlords. 

All this would serve to do, as far as your explanation provides, is make ADCs potentially more self-reliant (via itemization) than they already are, since they wouldn't need a lifesteal item. Instead of using alienated keystones, why don't you focus purely on what the intent is? If its self-healing, allow ALL champs to be able to make use of it, not just a certain class. You already have things in place to counter it, so it wouldn't be broken {{item:3165}} {{item:3033}} 

Is there a reason you don't try to encourage multi-role use of certain keystones, like the new warlord's providing something like wota/gunblade's sustain as you drop in health as opposed to just lifesteal?

Don't use Vlad as an excuse for this one because he's getting reworked and you KNOW this. You could easily give him compensation nerfs if he became too powerful and it wouldn't matter in the long run because there's an incoming rework.

While it is possible I doubt that it will pan out in practice because of the other stats that the lifesteal items have. MS has the QSS active which can't be bought elsewhere, BT replacements sacrifice either quite a bit of ad or survivability, blade has its niche as % health damage for adcs, and Deaths Dance's healing off of physical spells is also unique. Your more likely to just end up having a greater total quantity of lifesteal in your build rather then forgo a lifesteal item altogether.
